text: I move around the table and lean closer to her. She’s slumped against the edge, breathing lightly—like she’s finally stolen a moment of peace.

I slide the candleholder aside, careful not to let the firelight sting her eyelids. Then I bend down slowly, slipping my arm beneath her shoulders. She’s lighter than I expected—so light it tightens something in my chest.
“…I’ll take you back to your room.”
I carry her upstairs. Just as I reach the turn in the staircase, my foot slips—like I’ve stepped on a smear of leftover grease.
My heart drops. I don’t have time to steady myself; my knee hits the step first, and my whole body pitches forward.

I do everything I can to shield her, but she still jolts in my arms. Her eyelashes twitch sharply, and the next second she’s awake. Those grey-blue eyes gleam in the darkness—bright enough to be frightening.
“I’m sorry! I—I slipped… I was trying to take you back to your room.”
She looks at me. There’s no anger in her eyes—only the exhaustion of being dragged out of a rare moment of calm. She takes a deep breath, then steadies herself and steps out of my arms.
She grips the railing. Her steps are unsteady, but stubborn. After two steps, she glances back at me—checking, as if to make sure I didn’t fall again.
She pushes the door open and goes inside on her own. The door closes softly behind her—so lightly it still feels like being shut out.
I stand at the top of the stairs, rubbing my aching knee, a dull tightness spreading through my chest.
